## Mikhail Bulgakov's Biography and Historical Context

Mikhail Afanasyevich Bulgakov (1891–1940) was a Russian and Soviet novelist and playwright.(no content)He has become the most popular Russian writer of the twentieth century, even though his works were banned for decades after his death due to the repressive Soviet censorship of literature.

### Early Life and Background
Mikhail Bulgakov was one of seven children born to Afanasiy Ivanovich Bulgakov, a prominent Orthodox theologian, and Varvara Mikhailovna Bulgakov, a teacher.(no content)Curtis provides a fresh account of Bulgakov's idyllic childhood and youth in Kiev, which was swept away in the turmoil of the First World War, the Russian Revolution and Civil War.

### Censorship and Soviet Literary Context in the 1930s

The 1930s represented an extremely dangerous period for writers in the Soviet Union. In 1929, the Russian Association of Proletarian Writers became the official government agency overseeing the political content of literary works.(no content)The Master is a writer who is plagued both by his own mental problems and the harsh political criticism faced by most Soviet writers in 1930s Moscow in the Stalinist Soviet Union.(no content)Mikhail Bulgakov is one of the most iconic Russian authors. But his life as a writer in Moscow from the early 1920s until 1940 was replete with informants and searches, censorship and secrecy, until it ended suddenly and tragically at the age of 49.

### "The Master and Margarita" - Creation and Suppression

The Master and Margarita (Russian: Мастер и Маргарита) is a novel by Mikhail Bulgakov, written in the Soviet Union between 1928 and 1940.(no content)His great novel, The Master and Margarita (published only in 1973), was written in complete secrecy during the 1930s for fear of the writer being arrested and shot.

The novel's creation reflects the extreme censorship of the era. Bulgakov had to rewrite the novel from memory after he burned the draft manuscript in 1930, as he could not see a future as a writer in the Soviet Union at a time of widespread political repression. This event is reflected in the novel itself through the memorable and much-quoted line "manuscripts don't burn" (рукописи не горят).

### Publication and Historical Impact

A censored version, with several chapters cut by editors, was published posthumously in Moscow magazine in 1966–1967 by his widow Elena Bulgakova.(no content)His widow, who was the inspiration for his Margarita, recognized the inherent danger of his satirical portrayal of Soviet bureaucracy and hid the manuscript until after the death of Stalin. Heavily censored, The Master and Margarita first appeared in serialized form in 1966 and 1967. Only in 1973 was it published in its entirety.

### Literary Significance and Themes

Bulgakov employs Aesopian language in order to criticize the hypocrisy of Soviet society. He makes a commentary on the flaws of Soviet society by referencing distinct issues such as the housing crisis, corruption and the secret police.(no content)The novel The Master and Margarita is a critique of Soviet society and its literary establishment.(no content)The Master is an author surrogate for Bulgakov himself, as he represents Bulgakov's own struggles with censorship, criticism and stifled creativity in the Soviet Union.
